To turn content views into advertising dollars, Verizon wants to use and share the behavioral data it collects on its Internet subscribers  —   including records such as its customers’ Web browsing and location history.

Yahoo had the same business model as CNN and the New York Times  —   build up a large audience and then make money by selling ads  —   so it was natural for Yahoo to think of itself as being in the same industry.

As Bloomberg puts it, ”Yahoo got fat over the years as it navigated the rapidly changing industry in a sprawling effort to be all things to all people  —   from search to shopping to news outlet to blogging hub”.
The industry has fought the proposed requirement from the Federal Communications Commission, saying it would make it harder to adapt to the future.
But AOL and Yahoo were struggling in an increasingly mobile online world dominated by Google and Facebook.

Yahoo was never really able to adapt its technology and culture for a   internet that was focused on social media and mobile devices, and so it steadily fell behind rivals such as Google and Facebook.

The deal also could spell an end of the tenure of Yahoo’s   CEO Marissa Mayer.
Two years ago  —   an epoch in Silicon Valley time  —   AOL chief executive Tim Armstrong proposed a merger to Yahoo chief executive Marissa Mayer.
The agreement, slated to be announced early Monday, is expected to end Yahoo Chief Executive Marissa Mayer’s floundering,   effort to turn around the once mighty but recently struggling Web pioneer.
Yahoo’s board approved the sale of Yahoo’s core business to Verizon in a deal valued at $4.
The details of Verizon’s deal did not specify the value of the ”!” at the end of ”Yahoo!”

But Verizon’s compelling pitch to Yahoo’s Board of Directors was that they already operate in similar businesses, there is no financing contingency, and the scale of the combined advertising tech assets is a credible threat to challenge the Facebook and Google oligopoly.
After all, Yahoo’s stock market valuation alone is $38 billion.
But the stock market didn’t seem very optimistic about the chances.
With the stock market tanking in the “Great Recession” and Yahoo disastrously having gone through 3 new CEOs in four years, Mayer was hired in July 2012 with the stock at $15.

4 billion purchase of AOL Headed by former Google exec Tim Armstrong, AOL is likewise licking its chops for Yahoo’s advertising tech tools, as well as its search engine and   service.
After the Verizon acquisition, signature Yahoo properties like its search engine, email service, photo sharing site Flickr, and blogging platform Tumblr will presumably continue operating.
Aside from the search, Yahoo also has finance, news, mail and other specialty verticals as well as the blogging site Tumblr and photo site Flickr.
Yahoo’s biggest value, however, has rested in its stakes in the Chinese online retail giant Alibaba and in Yahoo Japan  —   and those will remain with Yahoo.
The deal does include Yahoo’s large   assets in Silicon Valley, but does not include the company’s intellectual property and stakes in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan.
With Yahoo’s core business sold off, the Sunnyvale, Calif. firm founded in 1994 by Jerry Yang and David Filo must now decide what to do with its Yahoo Japan and Alibaba stakes.

According to Yahoo’s release about the deal, ”Yahoo will be integrated with AOL under Marni Walden, EVP and President of the Product Innovation and New Businesses organization at Verizon”  —   suggesting that Mayer may end up out of a job, with the combined   unit reporting to Tim Armstrong, who was AOL’s CEO prior to the Verizon sale and was asked to stay on afterward.
Armstrong negotiated the AOL merger with Verizon and now will be swallowing Yahoo.

Armstrong, who had tried and failed to convince Mayer to buy AOL in 2014 before selling to Verizon, will create the   internet advertiser with the Yahoo deal  —   albeit far behind Google and Facebook, which together control more than half of the online advertising market, according to eMarketer.
